     210                 :            :     // By convention a negative value for flags indicates that the
     211                 :            :     // current network-enforced consensus rules should be used. In
     212                 :            :     // a future soft-fork scenario that would mean checking which
     213                 :            :     // rules would be enforced for the next block and setting the

     218                 :            :     // CheckFinalTx() uses ::ChainActive().Height()+1 to evaluate
     219                 :            :     // nLockTime because when IsFinalTx() is called within
     220                 :            :     // CBlock::AcceptBlock(), the height of the block *being*
     221                 :            :     // evaluated is what is used. Thus if we want to know if a
     222                 :            :     // transaction can be part of the *next* block, we need to call
     223                 :            :     // IsFinalTx() with one more than ::ChainActive().Height().

     356                 :            : 
     357                 :            : /* Make mempool consistent after a reorg, by re-adding or recursively erasing
     358                 :            :  * disconnected block transactions from the mempool, and also removing any
     359                 :            :  * other transactions from the mempool that are no longer valid given the new
     360                 :            :  * tip/height.
     361                 :            :  *
     362                 :            :  * Note: we assume that disconnectpool only contains transactions that are NOT
     363                 :            :  * confirmed in the current chain nor already in the mempool (otherwise,
     364                 :            :  * in-mempool descendants of such transactions would be removed).
     365                 :            :  *
     366                 :            :  * Passing fAddToMempool=false will skip trying to add the transactions back,
     367                 :            :  * and instead just erase from the mempool as needed.
     368                 :            :  */
     369                 :            : 
     370                 :         19 : static void UpdateMempoolForReorg(CTxMemPool& mempool, DisconnectedBlockTransactions& disconnectpool, bool fAddToMempool) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, mempool.cs)
     371                 :            : {
     372                 :         19 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
     373                 :         19 :     AssertLockHeld(mempool.cs);
     374                 :         19 :     std::vector<uint256> vHashUpdate;
     375                 :            :     // disconnectpool's insertion_order index sorts the entries from
     376                 :            :     // oldest to newest, but the oldest entry will be the last tx from the
     377                 :            :     // latest mined block that was disconnected.
     378                 :            :     // Iterate disconnectpool in reverse, so that we add transactions
     379                 :            :     // back to the mempool starting with the earliest transaction that had
     380                 :            :     // been previously seen in a block.
     381                 :         19 :     auto it = disconnectpool.queuedTx.get<insertion_order>().rbegin();
     382         [ +  + ]:        453 :     while (it != disconnectpool.queuedTx.get<insertion_order>().rend()) {
     383                 :            :         // ignore validation errors in resurrected transactions
     384         [ +  - ]:        887 :         TxValidationState stateDummy;
     385   [ +  -  -  +  :        868 :         if (!fAddToMempool || (*it)->IsCoinBase() ||
                   -  - ]
     386         [ #  # ]:          0 :             !AcceptToMemoryPool(mempool, stateDummy, *it,
     387                 :            :                                 nullptr /* plTxnReplaced */, true /* bypass_limits */)) {
     388                 :            :             // If the transaction doesn't make it in to the mempool, remove any
     389                 :            :             // transactions that depend on it (which would now be orphans).
     390         [ +  - ]:        434 :             mempool.removeRecursive(**it, MemPoolRemovalReason::REORG);
     391   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :         } else if (mempool.exists((*it)->GetHash())) {
     392         [ #  # ]:          0 :             vHashUpdate.push_back((*it)->GetHash());
     393                 :            :         }
     394         [ +  - ]:        868 :         ++it;
     395                 :            :     }
     396                 :         19 :     disconnectpool.queuedTx.clear();
     397                 :            :     // AcceptToMemoryPool/addUnchecked all assume that new mempool entries have
     398                 :            :     // no in-mempool children, which is generally not true when adding
     399                 :            :     // previously-confirmed transactions back to the mempool.
     400                 :            :     // UpdateTransactionsFromBlock finds descendants of any transactions in
     401                 :            :     // the disconnectpool that were added back and cleans up the mempool state.
     402         [ +  - ]:         19 :     mempool.UpdateTransactionsFromBlock(vHashUpdate);
     403                 :            :

     405   [ +  -  +  -  :         38 :     mempool.removeForReorg(&::ChainstateActive().CoinsTip(), ::ChainActive().Tip()->nHeight + 1, STANDARD_LOCKTIME_VERIFY_FLAGS);

     458                 :            :     // We put the arguments we're handed into a struct, so we can pass them
     459                 :            :     // around easier.
     460                 :            :     struct ATMPArgs {
     461                 :            :         const CChainParams& m_chainparams;
     462                 :            :         TxValidationState &m_state;

     467                 :            :          * Return any outpoints which were not previously present in the coins

     480                 :            : 
     481                 :            : private:
     482                 :            :     // All the intermediate state that gets passed between the various levels
     483                 :            :     // of checking a given transaction.
     484                 :            :     struct Workspace {
     485                 :         74 :         Workspace(const CTransactionRef& ptx) : m_ptx(ptx), m_hash(ptx->GetHash()) {}
     486                 :            :         std::set<uint256> m_conflicts;
     487                 :            :         CTxMemPool::setEntries m_all_conflicting;

     495                 :            :

     497                 :            :         const uint256& m_hash;
     498                 :            :     };
     499                 :            : 
     500                 :            :     // Run the policy checks on a given transaction, excluding any script checks.
     501                 :            :     // Looks up inputs, calculates feerate, considers replacement, evaluates
     502                 :            :     // package limits, etc. As this function can be invoked for "free" by a peer,
     503                 :            :     // only tests that are fast should be done here (to avoid CPU DoS).
     504                 :            :     bool PreChecks(ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     505                 :            : 
     506                 :            :     // Run the script checks using our policy flags. As this can be slow, we should
     507                 :            :     // only invoke this on transactions that have otherwise passed policy checks.
     508                 :            :     bool PolicyScriptChecks(ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws, PrecomputedTransactionData& txdata) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     509                 :            : 
     510                 :            :     // Re-run the script checks, using consensus flags, and try to cache the
     511                 :            :     // result in the scriptcache. This should be done after
     512                 :            :     // PolicyScriptChecks(). This requires that all inputs either be in our
     513                 :            :     // utxo set or in the mempool.
     514                 :            :     bool ConsensusScriptChecks(ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws, PrecomputedTransactionData &txdata) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     515                 :            : 
     516                 :            :     // Try to add the transaction to the mempool, removing any conflicts first.
     517                 :            :     // Returns true if the transaction is in the mempool after any size
     518                 :            :     // limiting is performed, false otherwise.
     519                 :            :     bool Finalize(ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     520                 :            : 
     521                 :            :     // Compare a package's feerate against minimum allowed.

     614                 :            :                 // non-replaceable transactions. All inputs rather than just one

     704                 :         73 :     nModifiedFees = nFees;

     706                 :            : 
     707                 :            :     // Keep track of transactions that spend a coinbase, which we re-scan
     708                 :            :     // during reorgs to ensure COINBASE_MATURITY is still met.
     709                 :         73 :     bool fSpendsCoinbase = false;
     710         [ +  - ]:         73 :     for (const CTxIn &txin : tx.vin) {

     720         [ +  - ]:         73 :     unsigned int nSize = entry->GetTxSize();
     721                 :            : 
     722         [ -  + ]:         73 :     if (nSigOpsCost > MAX_STANDARD_TX_SIGOPS_COST)
     723   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :         return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_NOT_STANDARD, "bad-txns-too-many-sigops",
     724   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                 strprintf("%d", nSigOpsCost));
                   #  # ]
     725                 :            : 
     726                 :            :     // No transactions are allowed below minRelayTxFee except from disconnected
     727                 :            :     // blocks
     728   [ +  +  +  -  :         73 :     if (!bypass_limits && !CheckFeeRate(nSize, nModifiedFees, state)) return false;
                   +  - ]
     729                 :            : 
     730   [ +  -  -  + ]:        146 :     const CTxMemPool::setEntries setIterConflicting = m_pool.GetIterSet(setConflicts);
     731                 :            :     // Calculate in-mempool ancestors, up to a limit.
     732         [ -  + ]:         73 :     if (setConflicts.size() == 1) {
     733                 :            :         // In general, when we receive an RBF transaction with mempool conflicts, we want to know whether we
     734                 :            :         // would meet the chain limits after the conflicts have been removed. However, there isn't a practical
     735                 :            :         // way to do this short of calculating the ancestor and descendant sets with an overlay cache of
     736                 :            :         // changed mempool entries. Due to both implementation and runtime complexity concerns, this isn't
     737                 :            :         // very realistic, thus we only ensure a limited set of transactions are RBF'able despite mempool
     738                 :            :         // conflicts here. Importantly, we need to ensure that some transactions which were accepted using
     739                 :            :         // the below carve-out are able to be RBF'ed, without impacting the security the carve-out provides
     740                 :            :         // for off-chain contract systems (see link in the comment below).
     741                 :            :         //
     742                 :            :         // Specifically, the subset of RBF transactions which we allow despite chain limits are those which
     743                 :            :         // conflict directly with exactly one other transaction (but may evict children of said transaction),
     744                 :            :         // and which are not adding any new mempool dependencies. Note that the "no new mempool dependencies"
     745                 :            :         // check is accomplished later, so we don't bother doing anything about it here, but if BIP 125 is
     746                 :            :         // amended, we may need to move that check to here instead of removing it wholesale.
     747                 :            :         //
     748                 :            :         // Such transactions are clearly not merging any existing packages, so we are only concerned with
     749                 :            :         // ensuring that (a) no package is growing past the package size (not count) limits and (b) we are
     750                 :            :         // not allowing something to effectively use the (below) carve-out spot when it shouldn't be allowed
     751                 :            :         // to.
     752                 :            :         //
     753                 :            :         // To check these we first check if we meet the RBF criteria, above, and increment the descendant
     754                 :            :         // limits by the direct conflict and its descendants (as these are recalculated in
     755                 :            :         // CalculateMempoolAncestors by assuming the new transaction being added is a new descendant, with no
     756                 :            :         // removals, of each parent's existing dependent set). The ancestor count limits are unmodified (as
     757                 :            :         // the ancestor limits should be the same for both our new transaction and any conflicts).
     758                 :            :         // We don't bother incrementing m_limit_descendants by the full removal count as that limit never comes
     759                 :            :         // into force here (as we're only adding a single transaction).
     760         [ #  # ]:          0 :         assert(setIterConflicting.size() == 1);
     761                 :          0 :         CTxMemPool::txiter conflict = *setIterConflicting.begin();
     762                 :            : 
     763                 :          0 :         m_limit_descendants += 1;
     764                 :          0 :         m_limit_descendant_size += conflict->GetSizeWithDescendants();
     765                 :            :     }
     766                 :            : 
     767         [ +  - ]:        146 :     std::string errString;
     768   [ +  -  -  + ]:         73 :     if (!m_pool.CalculateMemPoolAncestors(*entry, setAncestors, m_limit_ancestors, m_limit_ancestor_size, m_limit_descendants, m_limit_descendant_size, errString)) {
     769                 :          0 :         setAncestors.clear();
     770                 :            :         // If CalculateMemPoolAncestors fails second time, we want the original error string.
     771         [ #  # ]:          0 :         std::string dummy_err_string;
     772                 :            :         // Contracting/payment channels CPFP carve-out:
     773                 :            :         // If the new transaction is relatively small (up to 40k weight)
     774                 :            :         // and has at most one ancestor (ie ancestor limit of 2, including
     775                 :            :         // the new transaction), allow it if its parent has exactly the
     776                 :            :         // descendant limit descendants.
     777                 :            :         //
     778                 :            :         // This allows protocols which rely on distrusting counterparties
     779                 :            :         // being able to broadcast descendants of an unconfirmed transaction
     780                 :            :         // to be secure by simply only having two immediately-spendable
     781                 :            :         // outputs - one for each counterparty. For more info on the uses for
     782                 :            :         // this, see https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-dev/2018-November/016518.html
     783   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :         if (nSize >  EXTRA_DESCENDANT_TX_SIZE_LIMIT ||
     784         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 !m_pool.CalculateMemPoolAncestors(*entry, setAncestors, 2, m_limit_ancestor_size, m_limit_descendants + 1, m_limit_descendant_size + EXTRA_DESCENDANT_TX_SIZE_LIMIT, dummy_err_string)) {
     785   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :             return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, "too-long-mempool-chain", errString);
             #  #  #  # ]
     786                 :            :         }
     787                 :            :     }
     788                 :            : 
     789                 :            :     // A transaction that spends outputs that would be replaced by it is invalid. Now
     790                 :            :     // that we have the set of all ancestors we can detect this
     791                 :            :     // pathological case by making sure setConflicts and setAncestors don't
     792                 :            :     // intersect.
     793         [ -  + ]:         73 :     for (CTxMemPool::txiter ancestorIt : setAncestors)
     794                 :            :     {
     795                 :          0 :         const uint256 &hashAncestor = ancestorIt->GetTx().GetHash();
     796         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (setConflicts.count(hashAncestor))
     797                 :            :         {
     798   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_CONSENSUS, "bad-txns-spends-conflicting-tx",
     799         [ #  # ]:          0 :                     strprintf("%s spends conflicting transaction %s",
     800   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :                         hash.ToString(),
     801   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                         hashAncestor.ToString()));
             #  #  #  # ]
     802                 :            :         }
     803                 :            :     }
     804                 :            : 
     805                 :            :     // Check if it's economically rational to mine this transaction rather
     806                 :            :     // than the ones it replaces.
     807                 :         73 :     nConflictingFees = 0;
     808                 :         73 :     nConflictingSize = 0;
     809                 :         73 :     uint64_t nConflictingCount = 0;
     810                 :            : 
     811                 :            :     // If we don't hold the lock allConflicting might be incomplete; the
     812                 :            :     // subsequent RemoveStaged() and addUnchecked() calls don't guarantee
     813                 :            :     // mempool consistency for us.
     814         [ -  + ]:         73 :     fReplacementTransaction = setConflicts.size();
     815         [ -  + ]:         73 :     if (fReplacementTransaction)
     816                 :            :     {
     817         [ #  # ]:          0 :         CFeeRate newFeeRate(nModifiedFees, nSize);
     818         [ -  + ]:         73 :         std::set<uint256> setConflictsParents;
     819                 :          0 :         const int maxDescendantsToVisit = 100;
     820         [ #  # ]:          0 :         for (const auto& mi : setIterConflicting) {
     821                 :            :             // Don't allow the replacement to reduce the feerate of the
     822                 :            :             // mempool.
     823                 :            :             //
     824                 :            :             // We usually don't want to accept replacements with lower
     825                 :            :             // feerates than what they replaced as that would lower the
     826                 :            :             // feerate of the next block. Requiring that the feerate always
     827                 :            :             // be increased is also an easy-to-reason about way to prevent
     828                 :            :             // DoS attacks via replacements.
     829                 :            :             //
     830                 :            :             // We only consider the feerates of transactions being directly
     831                 :            :             // replaced, not their indirect descendants. While that does
     832                 :            :             // mean high feerate children are ignored when deciding whether
     833                 :            :             // or not to replace, we do require the replacement to pay more
     834                 :            :             // overall fees too, mitigating most cases.
     835   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             CFeeRate oldFeeRate(mi->GetModifiedFee(), mi->GetTxSize());
     836         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (newFeeRate <= oldFeeRate)
     837                 :            :             {
     838   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                 return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, "insufficient fee",
                   #  # ]
     839         [ #  # ]:          0 :                         strprintf("rejecting replacement %s; new feerate %s <= old feerate %s",
     840   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :                             hash.ToString(),
     841   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :                             newFeeRate.ToString(),
     842   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                             oldFeeRate.ToString()));
             #  #  #  # ]
     843                 :            :             }
     844                 :            : 
     845         [ #  # ]:          0 :             for (const CTxIn &txin : mi->GetTx().vin)
     846                 :            :             {
     847         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 setConflictsParents.insert(txin.prevout.hash);
     848                 :            :             }
     849                 :            : 
     850                 :          0 :             nConflictingCount += mi->GetCountWithDescendants();
     851                 :            :         }
     852                 :            :         // This potentially overestimates the number of actual descendants
     853                 :            :         // but we just want to be conservative to avoid doing too much
     854                 :            :         // work.
     855         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (nConflictingCount <= maxDescendantsToVisit) {
     856                 :            :             // If not too many to replace, then calculate the set of
     857                 :            :             // transactions that would have to be evicted
     858         [ #  # ]:          0 :             for (CTxMemPool::txiter it : setIterConflicting) {
     859         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 m_pool.CalculateDescendants(it, allConflicting);
     860                 :            :             }
     861         [ #  # ]:          0 :             for (CTxMemPool::txiter it : allConflicting) {

     863         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 nConflictingSize += it->GetTxSize();
     864                 :            :             }
     865                 :            :         } else {
     866   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, "too many potential replacements",
     867         [ #  # ]:          0 :                     strprintf("rejecting replacement %s; too many potential replacements (%d > %d)\n",
     868         [ #  # ]:          0 :                         hash.ToString(),
     869                 :            :                         nConflictingCount,
     870   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                         maxDescendantsToVisit));
                   #  # ]
     871                 :            :         }
     872                 :            : 
     873         [ #  # ]:          0 :         for (unsigned int j = 0; j < tx.vin.size(); j++)
     874                 :            :         {
     875                 :            :             // We don't want to accept replacements that require low
     876                 :            :             // feerate junk to be mined first. Ideally we'd keep track of
     877                 :            :             // the ancestor feerates and make the decision based on that,
     878                 :            :             // but for now requiring all new inputs to be confirmed works.
     879                 :            :             //
     880                 :            :             // Note that if you relax this to make RBF a little more useful,
     881                 :            :             // this may break the CalculateMempoolAncestors RBF relaxation,
     882                 :            :             // above. See the comment above the first CalculateMempoolAncestors
     883                 :            :             // call for more info.
     884         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (!setConflictsParents.count(tx.vin[j].prevout.hash))
     885                 :            :             {
     886                 :            :                 // Rather than check the UTXO set - potentially expensive -
     887                 :            :                 // it's cheaper to just check if the new input refers to a
     888                 :            :                 // tx that's in the mempool.
     889   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :                 if (m_pool.exists(tx.vin[j].prevout.hash)) {
     890   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :                     return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, "replacement-adds-unconfirmed",
     891         [ #  # ]:          0 :                             strprintf("replacement %s adds unconfirmed input, idx %d",
     892   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                                 hash.ToString(), j));
             #  #  #  # ]
     893                 :            :                 }
     894                 :            :             }
     895                 :            :         }
     896                 :            : 
     897                 :            :         // The replacement must pay greater fees than the transactions it
     898                 :            :         // replaces - if we did the bandwidth used by those conflicting
     899                 :            :         // transactions would not be paid for.
     900         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (nModifiedFees < nConflictingFees)
     901                 :            :         {
     902   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, "insufficient fee",

     904   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                         hash.ToString(), FormatMoney(nModifiedFees), FormatMoney(nConflictingFees)));
          #  #  #  #  #  
          #  #  #  #  #  
                   #  # ]
     905                 :            :         }
     906                 :            : 
     907                 :            :         // Finally in addition to paying more fees than the conflicts the
     908                 :            :         // new transaction must pay for its own bandwidth.
     909                 :          0 :         CAmount nDeltaFees = nModifiedFees - nConflictingFees;
     910   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :         if (nDeltaFees < ::incrementalRelayFee.GetFee(nSize))
     911                 :            :         {

     917                 :            :         }
     918                 :            :     }
     919                 :            :     return true;
     920                 :            : }

     949                 :         73 : bool MemPoolAccept::ConsensusScriptChecks(ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws, PrecomputedTransactionData& txdata)
     950                 :            : {
     951                 :         73 :     const CTransaction& tx = *ws.m_ptx;
     952                 :         73 :     const uint256& hash = ws.m_hash;
     953                 :            : 
     954                 :         73 :     TxValidationState &state = args.m_state;
     955                 :         73 :     const CChainParams& chainparams = args.m_chainparams;
     956                 :            : 
     957                 :            :     // Check again against the current block tip's script verification
     958                 :            :     // flags to cache our script execution flags. This is, of course,
     959                 :            :     // useless if the next block has different script flags from the
     960                 :            :     // previous one, but because the cache tracks script flags for us it
     961                 :            :     // will auto-invalidate and we'll just have a few blocks of extra
     962                 :            :     // misses on soft-fork activation.
     963                 :            :     //
     964                 :            :     // This is also useful in case of bugs in the standard flags that cause
     965                 :            :     // transactions to pass as valid when they're actually invalid. For
     966                 :            :     // instance the STRICTENC flag was incorrectly allowing certain
     967                 :            :     // CHECKSIG NOT scripts to pass, even though they were invalid.
     968                 :            :     //
     969                 :            :     // There is a similar check in CreateNewBlock() to prevent creating
     970                 :            :     // invalid blocks (using TestBlockValidity), however allowing such
     971                 :            :     // transactions into the mempool can be exploited as a DoS attack.
     972         [ +  - ]:        146 :     unsigned int currentBlockScriptVerifyFlags = GetBlockScriptFlags(::ChainActive().Tip(), chainparams.GetConsensus());
     973         [ -  + ]:         73 :     if (!CheckInputsFromMempoolAndCache(tx, state, m_view, m_pool, currentBlockScriptVerifyFlags, txdata)) {
     974   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :         return error("%s: BUG! PLEASE REPORT THIS! CheckInputScripts failed against latest-block but not STANDARD flags %s, %s",
     975   [ -  -  -  - ]:         73 :                 __func__, hash.ToString(), state.ToString());
     976                 :            :     }
     977                 :            : 
     978                 :            :     return true;
     979                 :            : }
     980                 :            : 
     981                 :         71 : bool MemPoolAccept::Finalize(ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws)

    1032                 :            :

    1034                 :            : 
    1035   [ +  -  +  + ]:         74 :     if (!PreChecks(args, workspace)) return false;
    1036                 :            : 
    1037                 :            :     // Only compute the precomputed transaction data if we need to verify
    1038                 :            :     // scripts (ie, other policy checks pass). We perform the inexpensive
    1039                 :            :     // checks first and avoid hashing and signature verification unless those
    1040                 :            :     // checks pass, to mitigate CPU exhaustion denial-of-service attacks.
    1041                 :        147 :     PrecomputedTransactionData txdata;

    1046                 :            :

    1049                 :            :

    1059                 :            : /** (try to) add transaction to memory pool with a specified acceptance time **/
    1060                 :         74 : static bool AcceptToMemoryPoolWithTime(const CChainParams& chainparams, CTxMemPool& pool, TxValidationState &state, const CTransactionRef &tx,

    1062                 :            :                         bool bypass_limits, bool test_accept, CAmount* fee_out=nullptr) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main)
    1063                 :            : {
    1064         [ +  - ]:         74 :     std::vector<COutPoint> coins_to_uncache;
    1065                 :         74 :     MemPoolAccept::ATMPArgs args { chainparams, state, nAcceptTime, plTxnReplaced, bypass_limits, coins_to_uncache, test_accept, fee_out };
    1066   [ +  -  +  - ]:         74 :     bool res = MemPoolAccept(pool).AcceptSingleTransaction(tx, args);
    1067         [ +  + ]:         74 :     if (!res) {
    1068                 :            :         // Remove coins that were not present in the coins cache before calling ATMPW;
    1069                 :            :         // this is to prevent memory DoS in case we receive a large number of
    1070                 :            :         // invalid transactions that attempt to overrun the in-memory coins cache
    1071                 :            :         // (`CCoinsViewCache::cacheCoins`).
    1072                 :            : 
    1073         [ -  + ]:          1 :         for (const COutPoint& hashTx : coins_to_uncache)
    1074   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             ::ChainstateActive().CoinsTip().Uncache(hashTx);
    1075                 :            :     }

    1077   [ +  -  -  + ]:        148 :     BlockValidationState state_dummy;
    1078   [ +  -  +  - ]:         74 :     ::ChainstateActive().FlushStateToDisk(chainparams, state_dummy, FlushStateMode::PERIODIC);
    1079                 :        148 :     return res;
    1080                 :            : }
    1081                 :            : 
    1082                 :         74 : bool AcceptToMemoryPool(CTxMemPool& pool, TxValidationState &state, const CTransactionRef &tx,

    1376                 :          4 : static void CheckForkWarningConditionsOnNewFork(CBlockIndex* pindexNewForkTip) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main)

    1383                 :            :     {

    1391                 :            :     // We define a condition where we should warn the user about as a fork of at least 7 blocks
    1392                 :            :     // with a tip within 72 blocks (+/- 12 hours if no one mines it) of ours
    1393                 :            :     // We use 7 blocks rather arbitrarily as it represents just under 10% of sustained network
    1394                 :            :     // hash rate operating on the fork.
    1395                 :            :     // or a chain that is entirely longer than ours and invalid (note that this should be detected by both)
    1396                 :            :     // We define it this way because it allows us to only store the highest fork tip (+ base) which meets
    1397                 :            :     // the 7-block condition and from this always have the most-likely-to-cause-warning fork

    1479                 :        465 : void InitScriptExecutionCache() {
    1480                 :            :     // Setup the salted hasher
    1481                 :        465 :     uint256 nonce = GetRandHash();

    1483                 :            :     // this chunk, which makes later hash computations more efficient. We
    1484                 :            :     // just write our 32-byte entropy twice to fill the 64 bytes.
    1485                 :        465 :     g_scriptExecutionCacheHasher.Write(nonce.begin(), 32);
    1486                 :        465 :     g_scriptExecutionCacheHasher.Write(nonce.begin(), 32);
    1487                 :            :     // nMaxCacheSize is unsigned. If -maxsigcachesize is set to zero,
    1488                 :            :     // setup_bytes creates the minimum possible cache (2 elements).

    1494                 :            : 
    1495                 :            : /**
    1496                 :            :  * Check whether all of this transaction's input scripts succeed.
    1497                 :            :  *
    1498                 :            :  * This involves ECDSA signature checks so can be computationally intensive. This function should
    1499                 :            :  * only be called after the cheap sanity checks in CheckTxInputs passed.
    1500                 :            :  *
    1501                 :            :  * If pvChecks is not nullptr, script checks are pushed onto it instead of being performed inline. Any
    1502                 :            :  * script checks which are not necessary (eg due to script execution cache hits) are, obviously,
    1503                 :            :  * not pushed onto pvChecks/run.
    1504                 :            :  *
    1505                 :            :  * Setting cacheSigStore/cacheFullScriptStore to false will remove elements from the corresponding cache
    1506                 :            :  * which are matched. This is useful for checking blocks where we will likely never need the cache
    1507                 :            :  * entry again.
    1508                 :            :  *
    1509                 :            :  * Note that we may set state.reason to NOT_STANDARD for extra soft-fork flags in flags, block-checking
    1510                 :            :  * callers should probably reset it to CONSENSUS in such cases.
    1511                 :            :  *
    1512                 :            :  * Non-static (and re-declared) in src/test/txvalidationcache_tests.cpp
    1513                 :            :  */
    1514                 :     259340 : bool CheckInputScripts(const CTransaction& tx, TxValidationState &state, const CCoinsViewCache &inputs, unsigned int flags, bool cacheSigStore, bool cacheFullScriptStore, PrecomputedTransactionData& txdata, std::vector<CScriptCheck> *pvChecks) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main)

    1692                 :            :         // outputs. This implies that it must be present for some other output of the same tx.
    1693                 :          0 :         const Coin& alternate = AccessByTxid(view, out.hash);
    1694         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (!alternate.IsSpent()) {
    1695                 :          0 :             undo.nHeight = alternate.nHeight;
    1696                 :          0 :             undo.fCoinBase = alternate.fCoinBase;

    1698                 :            :             return DISCONNECT_FAILED; // adding output for transaction without known metadata
    1699                 :            :         }
    1700                 :            :     }

    1702                 :            :     // possible_overwrite parameter to AddCoin must be set to true. We have

    1705                 :            :     // existed and it is an overwrite.

    1801                 :            :         // rev files are written in block height order, whereas blk files are written as blocks come in (often out of order)
    1802                 :            :         // we want to flush the rev (undo) file once we've written the last block, which is indicated by the last height
    1803                 :            :         // in the block file info as below; note that this does not catch the case where the undo writes are keeping up
    1804                 :            :         // with the block writes (usually when a synced up node is getting newly mined blocks) -- this case is caught in
    1805                 :            :         // the FindBlockPos function

    1843                 :            : /**

    1868                 :            : static ThresholdConditionCache warningcache[VERSIONBITS_NUM_BITS] GUARDED_BY(cs_main);
    1869                 :            :

    1875                 :            : {

    1878                 :            : 
    1879                 :       6724 : static unsigned int GetBlockScriptFlags(const CBlockIndex* pindex, const Consensus::Params& consensusparams) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main) {

    1882                 :       6724 :     unsigned int flags = SCRIPT_VERIFY_NONE;

    1884                 :            :     // BIP16 didn't become active until Apr 1 2012 (on mainnet, and
    1885                 :            :     // retroactively applied to testnet)
    1886                 :            :     // However, only one historical block violated the P2SH rules (on both
    1887                 :            :     // mainnet and testnet), so for simplicity, always leave P2SH
    1888                 :            :     // on except for the one violating block.

    1929                 :            : 
    1930                 :            : 
    1931                 :            : 
    1932                 :            : static int64_t nTimeCheck = 0;
    1933                 :            : static int64_t nTimeForks = 0;

    1939                 :            : static int64_t nBlocksTotal = 0;
    1940                 :            : 
    1941                 :            : /** Apply the effects of this block (with given index) on the UTXO set represented by coins.
    1942                 :            :  *  Validity checks that depend on the UTXO set are also done; ConnectBlock()
    1943                 :            :  *  can fail if those validity checks fail (among other reasons). */
    1944                 :       6742 : bool CChainState::ConnectBlock(const CBlock& block, BlockValidationState& state, CBlockIndex* pindex,
    1945                 :            :                   CCoinsViewCache& view, const CChainParams& chainparams, bool fJustCheck)
    1946                 :            : {
    1947         [ -  + ]:       6742 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    1948         [ -  + ]:       6742 :     assert(pindex);
    1949         [ -  + ]:       6742 :     assert(*pindex->phashBlock == block.GetHash());
    1950                 :       6742 :     int64_t nTimeStart = GetTimeMicros();
    1951                 :            : 
    1952                 :            :     // Check it again in case a previous version let a bad block in
    1953                 :            :     // NOTE: We don't currently (re-)invoke ContextualCheckBlock() or
    1954                 :            :     // ContextualCheckBlockHeader() here. This means that if we add a new
    1955                 :            :     // consensus rule that is enforced in one of those two functions, then we
    1956                 :            :     // may have let in a block that violates the rule prior to updating the
    1957                 :            :     // software, and we would NOT be enforcing the rule here. Fully solving
    1958                 :            :     // upgrade from one software version to the next after a consensus rule
    1959                 :            :     // change is potentially tricky and issue-specific (see RewindBlockIndex()
    1960                 :            :     // for one general approach that was used for BIP 141 deployment).
    1961                 :            :     // Also, currently the rule against blocks more than 2 hours in the future
    1962                 :            :     // is enforced in ContextualCheckBlockHeader(); we wouldn't want to
    1963                 :            :     // re-enforce that rule here (at least until we make it impossible for
    1964                 :            :     // GetAdjustedTime() to go backward).
    1965         [ -  + ]:       6742 :     if (!CheckBlock(block, state, chainparams.GetConsensus(), !fJustCheck, !fJustCheck)) {
    1966         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (state.GetResult() == BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_MUTATED) {
    1967                 :            :             // We don't write down blocks to disk if they may have been
    1968                 :            :             // corrupted, so this should be impossible unless we're having hardware
    1969                 :            :             // problems.
    1970   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :             return AbortNode(state, "Corrupt block found indicating potential hardware failure; shutting down");
                   #  # ]
    1971                 :            :         }
    1972   [ -  -  -  - ]:       6742 :         return error("%s: Consensus::CheckBlock: %s", __func__, state.ToString());
    1973                 :            :     }
    1974                 :            : 
    1975                 :            :     // verify that the view's current state corresponds to the previous block
    1976         [ +  + ]:       6833 :     uint256 hashPrevBlock = pindex->pprev == nullptr ? uint256() : pindex->pprev->GetBlockHash();
    1977         [ -  + ]:       6742 :     assert(hashPrevBlock == view.GetBestBlock());
    1978                 :            : 
    1979                 :       6742 :     nBlocksTotal++;
    1980                 :            : 
    1981                 :            :     // Special case for the genesis block, skipping connection of its transactions
    1982                 :            :     // (its coinbase is unspendable)
    1983         [ +  + ]:       6742 :     if (block.GetHash() == chainparams.GetConsensus().hashGenesisBlock) {
    1984         [ +  - ]:         91 :         if (!fJustCheck)
    1985                 :         91 :             view.SetBestBlock(pindex->GetBlockHash());
    1986                 :         91 :         return true;
    1987                 :            :     }
    1988                 :            : 
    1989                 :     215419 :     bool fScriptChecks = true;
    1990   [ +  +  +  + ]:     215546 :     if (!hashAssumeValid.IsNull()) {
    1991                 :            :         // We've been configured with the hash of a block which has been externally verified to have a valid history.
    1992                 :            :         // A suitable default value is included with the software and updated from time to time.  Because validity
    1993                 :            :         //  relative to a piece of software is an objective fact these defaults can be easily reviewed.
    1994                 :            :         // This setting doesn't force the selection of any particular chain but makes validating some faster by
    1995                 :            :         //  effectively caching the result of part of the verification.
    1996         [ -  + ]:        127 :         BlockMap::const_iterator  it = m_blockman.m_block_index.find(hashAssumeValid);
    1997         [ -  + ]:        127 :         if (it != m_blockman.m_block_index.end()) {
    1998                 :          0 :             if (it->second->GetAncestor(pindex->nHeight) == pindex &&
    1999   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :                 pindexBestHeader->GetAncestor(pindex->nHeight) == pindex &&
    2000         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 pindexBestHeader->nChainWork >= nMinimumChainWork) {
    2001                 :            :                 // This block is a member of the assumed verified chain and an ancestor of the best header.
    2002                 :            :                 // Script verification is skipped when connecting blocks under the
    2003                 :            :                 // assumevalid block. Assuming the assumevalid block is valid this
    2004                 :            :                 // is safe because block merkle hashes are still computed and checked,
    2005                 :            :                 // Of course, if an assumed valid block is invalid due to false scriptSigs
    2006                 :            :                 // this optimization would allow an invalid chain to be accepted.
    2007                 :            :                 // The equivalent time check discourages hash power from extorting the network via DOS attack
    2008                 :            :                 //  into accepting an invalid block through telling users they must manually set assumevalid.
    2009                 :            :                 //  Requiring a software change or burying the invalid block, regardless of the setting, makes
    2010                 :            :                 //  it hard to hide the implication of the demand.  This also avoids having release candidates
    2011                 :            :                 //  that are hardly doing any signature verification at all in testing without having to
    2012                 :            :                 //  artificially set the default assumed verified block further back.
    2013                 :            :                 // The test against nMinimumChainWork prevents the skipping when denied access to any chain at
    2014                 :            :                 //  least as good as the expected chain.
    2015                 :          0 :                 fScriptChecks = (GetBlockProofEquivalentTime(*pindexBestHeader, *pindex, *pindexBestHeader, chainparams.GetConsensus()) <= 60 * 60 * 24 * 7 * 2);
    2016                 :            :             }
    2017                 :            :         }
    2018                 :            :     }
    2019                 :            : 
    2020                 :       6651 :     int64_t nTime1 = GetTimeMicros(); nTimeCheck += nTime1 - nTimeStart;
    2021         [ +  - ]:       6651 :     LogPrint(BCLog::BENCH, "    - Sanity checks: %.2fms [%.2fs (%.2fms/blk)]\n", MILLI * (nTime1 - nTimeStart), nTimeCheck * MICRO, nTimeCheck * MILLI / nBlocksTotal);
    2022                 :            : 
    2023                 :            :     // Do not allow blocks that contain transactions which 'overwrite' older transactions,
    2024                 :            :     // unless those are already completely spent.
    2025                 :            :     // If such overwrites are allowed, coinbases and transactions depending upon those
    2026                 :            :     // can be duplicated to remove the ability to spend the first instance -- even after
    2027                 :            :     // being sent to another address.
    2028                 :            :     // See BIP30, CVE-2012-1909, and http://r6.ca/blog/20120206T005236Z.html for more information.
    2029                 :            :     // This logic is not necessary for memory pool transactions, as AcceptToMemoryPool
    2030                 :            :     // already refuses previously-known transaction ids entirely.
    2031                 :            :     // This rule was originally applied to all blocks with a timestamp after March 15, 2012, 0:00 UTC.
    2032                 :            :     // Now that the whole chain is irreversibly beyond that time it is applied to all blocks except the
    2033                 :            :     // two in the chain that violate it. This prevents exploiting the issue against nodes during their
    2034                 :            :     // initial block download.
    2035   [ -  +  -  - ]:       6651 :     bool fEnforceBIP30 = !((pindex->nHeight==91842 && pindex->GetBlockHash() == uint256S("0x00000000000a4d0a398161ffc163c503763b1f4360639393e0e4c8e300e0caec")) ||
    2036   [ -  +  -  - ]:       6651 :                            (pindex->nHeight==91880 && pindex->GetBlockHash() == uint256S("0x00000000000743f190a18c5577a3c2d2a1f610ae9601ac046a38084ccb7cd721")));
    2037                 :            : 
    2038                 :            :     // Once BIP34 activated it was not possible to create new duplicate coinbases and thus other than starting
    2039                 :            :     // with the 2 existing duplicate coinbase pairs, not possible to create overwriting txs.  But by the
    2040                 :            :     // time BIP34 activated, in each of the existing pairs the duplicate coinbase had overwritten the first
    2041                 :            :     // before the first had been spent.  Since those coinbases are sufficiently buried it's no longer possible to create further
    2042                 :            :     // duplicate transactions descending from the known pairs either.
    2043                 :            :     // If we're on the known chain at height greater than where BIP34 activated, we can save the db accesses needed for the BIP30 check.
    2044                 :            : 
    2045                 :            :     // BIP34 requires that a block at height X (block X) has its coinbase
    2046                 :            :     // scriptSig start with a CScriptNum of X (indicated height X).  The above
    2047                 :            :     // logic of no longer requiring BIP30 once BIP34 activates is flawed in the
    2048                 :            :     // case that there is a block X before the BIP34 height of 227,931 which has
    2049                 :            :     // an indicated height Y where Y is greater than X.  The coinbase for block
    2050                 :            :     // X would also be a valid coinbase for block Y, which could be a BIP30
    2051                 :            :     // violation.  An exhaustive search of all mainnet coinbases before the
    2052                 :            :     // BIP34 height which have an indicated height greater than the block height
    2053                 :            :     // reveals many occurrences. The 3 lowest indicated heights found are
    2054                 :            :     // 209,921, 490,897, and 1,983,702 and thus coinbases for blocks at these 3
    2055                 :            :     // heights would be the first opportunity for BIP30 to be violated.
    2056                 :            : 
    2057                 :            :     // The search reveals a great many blocks which have an indicated height
    2058                 :            :     // greater than 1,983,702, so we simply remove the optimization to skip
    2059                 :            :     // BIP30 checking for blocks at height 1,983,702 or higher.  Before we reach
    2060                 :            :     // that block in another 25 years or so, we should take advantage of a
    2061                 :            :     // future consensus change to do a new and improved version of BIP34 that
    2062                 :            :     // will actually prevent ever creating any duplicate coinbases in the
    2063                 :            :     // future.
    2064                 :       6651 :     static constexpr int BIP34_IMPLIES_BIP30_LIMIT = 1983702;
    2065                 :            : 
    2066                 :            :     // There is no potential to create a duplicate coinbase at block 209,921
    2067                 :            :     // because this is still before the BIP34 height and so explicit BIP30
    2068                 :            :     // checking is still active.
    2069                 :            : 
    2070                 :            :     // The final case is block 176,684 which has an indicated height of
    2071                 :            :     // 490,897. Unfortunately, this issue was not discovered until about 2 weeks
    2072                 :            :     // before block 490,897 so there was not much opportunity to address this
    2073                 :            :     // case other than to carefully analyze it and determine it would not be a
    2074                 :            :     // problem. Block 490,897 was, in fact, mined with a different coinbase than
    2075                 :            :     // block 176,684, but it is important to note that even if it hadn't been or
    2076                 :            :     // is remined on an alternate fork with a duplicate coinbase, we would still
    2077                 :            :     // not run into a BIP30 violation.  This is because the coinbase for 176,684
    2078                 :            :     // is spent in block 185,956 in transaction
    2079                 :            :     // d4f7fbbf92f4a3014a230b2dc70b8058d02eb36ac06b4a0736d9d60eaa9e8781.  This
    2080                 :            :     // spending transaction can't be duplicated because it also spends coinbase
    2081                 :            :     // 0328dd85c331237f18e781d692c92de57649529bd5edf1d01036daea32ffde29.  This
    2082                 :            :     // coinbase has an indicated height of over 4.2 billion, and wouldn't be
    2083                 :            :     // duplicatable until that height, and it's currently impossible to create a
    2084                 :            :     // chain that long. Nevertheless we may wish to consider a future soft fork
    2085                 :            :     // which retroactively prevents block 490,897 from creating a duplicate
    2086                 :            :     // coinbase. The two historical BIP30 violations often provide a confusing
    2087                 :            :     // edge case when manipulating the UTXO and it would be simpler not to have
    2088                 :            :     // another edge case to deal with.
    2089                 :            : 
    2090                 :            :     // testnet3 has no blocks before the BIP34 height with indicated heights
    2091                 :            :     // post BIP34 before approximately height 486,000,000 and presumably will
    2092                 :            :     // be reset before it reaches block 1,983,702 and starts doing unnecessary
    2093                 :            :     // BIP30 checking again.
    2094         [ -  + ]:       6651 :     assert(pindex->pprev);
    2095                 :       6651 :     CBlockIndex *pindexBIP34height = pindex->pprev->GetAncestor(chainparams.GetConsensus().BIP34Height);
    2096                 :            :     //Only continue to enforce if we're below BIP34 activation height or the block hash at that height doesn't correspond.
    2097   [ +  -  -  +  :       6651 :     fEnforceBIP30 = fEnforceBIP30 && (!pindexBIP34height || !(pindexBIP34height->GetBlockHash() == chainparams.GetConsensus().BIP34Hash));
                   -  - ]
    2098                 :            : 
    2099                 :            :     // TODO: Remove BIP30 checking from block height 1,983,702 on, once we have a
    2100                 :            :     // consensus change that ensures coinbases at those heights can not
    2101                 :            :     // duplicate earlier coinbases.
    2102         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (fEnforceBIP30 || pindex->nHeight >= BIP34_IMPLIES_BIP30_LIMIT) {
    2103         [ +  + ]:      14449 :         for (const auto& tx : block.vtx) {
    2104         [ +  + ]:      22979 :             for (size_t o = 0; o < tx->vout.size(); o++) {
    2105         [ -  + ]:      15181 :                 if (view.HaveCoin(COutPoint(tx->GetHash(), o))) {
    2106                 :          0 :                     LogPrintf("ERROR: ConnectBlock(): tried to overwrite transaction\n");
    2107   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                     return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_CONSENSUS, "bad-txns-BIP30");
             #  #  #  # ]
    2108                 :            :                 }
    2109                 :            :             }
    2110                 :            :         }
    2111                 :            :     }
    2112                 :            : 
    2113                 :            :     // Start enforcing BIP68 (sequence locks)
    2114                 :       6651 :     int nLockTimeFlags = 0;
    2115         [ -  + ]:       6651 :     if (pindex->nHeight >= chainparams.GetConsensus().CSVHeight) {
    2116                 :          0 :         nLockTimeFlags |= LOCKTIME_VERIFY_SEQUENCE;
    2117                 :            :     }
    2118                 :            : 
    2119                 :            :     // Get the script flags for this block
    2120                 :       6651 :     unsigned int flags = GetBlockScriptFlags(pindex, chainparams.GetConsensus());
    2121                 :            : 
    2122                 :       6651 :     int64_t nTime2 = GetTimeMicros(); nTimeForks += nTime2 - nTime1;
    2123         [ +  - ]:       6651 :     LogPrint(BCLog::BENCH, "    - Fork checks: %.2fms [%.2fs (%.2fms/blk)]\n", MILLI * (nTime2 - nTime1), nTimeForks * MICRO, nTimeForks * MILLI / nBlocksTotal);
    2124                 :            : 
    2125         [ +  - ]:      13393 :     CBlockUndo blockundo;
    2126                 :            : 
    2127                 :            :     // Precomputed transaction data pointers must not be invalidated
    2128                 :            :     // until after `control` has run the script checks (potentially
    2129                 :            :     // in multiple threads). Preallocate the vector size so a new allocation
    2130                 :            :     // doesn't invalidate pointers into the vector, and keep txsdata in scope
    2131                 :            :     // for as long as `control`.

    2495                 :            : /** Disconnect m_chain's tip.

    2588                 :       2969 :     std::vector<PerBlockConnectTrace>& GetBlocksConnected() {
    2589                 :            :         // We always keep one extra block at the end of our list because
    2590                 :            :         // blocks are added after all the conflicted transactions have
    2591                 :            :         // been filled in. Thus, the last entry should always be an empty

    2725                 :       3389 : void CChainState::PruneBlockIndexCandidates() {

    2735                 :            : 
    2736                 :            : /**

    2742                 :       2969 : bool CChainState::ActivateBestChainStep(BlockValidationState& state, const CChainParams& chainparams, CBlockIndex* pindexMostWork, const std::shared_ptr<const CBlock>& pblock, bool& fInvalidFound, ConnectTrace& connectTrace)

    2875                 :            :     // ABC maintains a fair degree of expensive-to-calculate internal state
    2876                 :            :     // because this function periodically releases cs_main so that it does not lock up other threads for too long
    2877                 :            :     // during large connects - and to allow for e.g. the callback queue to drain

    3002                 :         10 : bool CChainState::InvalidateBlock(BlockValidationState& state, const CChainParams& chainparams, CBlockIndex *pindex)

    3004                 :         10 :     CBlockIndex* to_mark_failed = pindex;
    3005                 :         10 :     bool pindex_was_in_chain = false;

    3007                 :            : 
    3008                 :            :     // We do not allow ActivateBestChain() to run while InvalidateBlock() is
    3009                 :            :     // running, as that could cause the tip to change while we disconnect
    3010                 :            :     // blocks.
    3011                 :         20 :     LOCK(m_cs_chainstate);
    3012                 :            : 
    3013                 :            :     // We'll be acquiring and releasing cs_main below, to allow the validation
    3014                 :            :     // callbacks to run. However, we should keep the block index in a
    3015                 :            :     // consistent state as we disconnect blocks -- in particular we need to
    3016                 :            :     // add equal-work blocks to setBlockIndexCandidates as we disconnect.
    3017                 :            :     // To avoid walking the block index repeatedly in search of candidates,
    3018                 :            :     // build a map once so that we can look up candidate blocks by chain
    3019                 :            :     // work as we go.
    3020   [ +  -  +  - ]:         20 :     std::multimap<const arith_uint256, CBlockIndex *> candidate_blocks_by_work;

    3022                 :         10 :     {
    3023         [ +  - ]:         10 :         LOCK(cs_main);

    3025                 :       1010 :             CBlockIndex *candidate = entry.second;
    3026                 :            :             // We don't need to put anything in our active chain into the
    3027                 :            :             // multimap, because those candidates will be found and considered
    3028                 :            :             // as we disconnect.

    3030                 :            :             // least as much work as where we expect the new tip to end up.

    3542                 :            : {
    3543         [ +  - ]:       6685 :     const int nHeight = pindexPrev == nullptr ? 0 : pindexPrev->nHeight + 1;
    3544                 :            : 
    3545                 :            :     // Start enforcing BIP113 (Median Time Past).
    3546                 :       6685 :     int nLockTimeFlags = 0;
    3547         [ -  + ]:       6685 :     if (nHeight >= consensusParams.CSVHeight) {
    3548         [ #  # ]:          0 :         assert(pindexPrev != nullptr);
    3549                 :            :         nLockTimeFlags |= LOCKTIME_MEDIAN_TIME_PAST;
    3550                 :            :     }
    3551                 :            : 
    3552                 :       6685 :     int64_t nLockTimeCutoff = (nLockTimeFlags & LOCKTIME_MEDIAN_TIME_PAST)
    3553         [ -  + ]:       6685 :                               ? pindexPrev->GetMedianTimePast()

    3559   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :             return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_CONSENSUS, "bad-txns-nonfinal", "non-final transaction");
             #  #  #  # ]
    3560                 :            :         }
    3561                 :            :     }
    3562                 :            : 
    3563                 :            :     // Enforce rule that the coinbase starts with serialized block height
    3564         [ -  + ]:       6685 :     if (nHeight >= consensusParams.BIP34Height)
    3565                 :            :     {

    3568   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             !std::equal(expect.begin(), expect.end(), block.vtx[0]->vin[0].scriptSig.begin())) {
    3569   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :             return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_CONSENSUS, "bad-cb-height", "block height mismatch in coinbase");
          #  #  #  #  #  
                      # ]
    3570                 :            :         }
    3571                 :            :     }
    3572                 :            : 
    3573                 :            :     // Validation for witness commitments.
    3574                 :            :     // * We compute the witness hash (which is the hash including witnesses) of all the block's transactions, except the
    3575                 :            :     //   coinbase (where 0x0000....0000 is used instead).
    3576                 :            :     // * The coinbase scriptWitness is a stack of a single 32-byte vector, containing a witness reserved value (unconstrained).
    3577                 :            :     // * We build a merkle tree with all those witness hashes as leaves (similar to the hashMerkleRoot in the block header).
    3578                 :            :     // * There must be at least one output whose scriptPubKey is a single 36-byte push, the first 4 bytes of which are
    3579                 :            :     //   {0xaa, 0x21, 0xa9, 0xed}, and the following 32 bytes are SHA256^2(witness root, witness reserved value). In case there are
    3580                 :            :     //   multiple, the last one is used.
    3581                 :       6685 :     bool fHaveWitness = false;
    3582         [ +  + ]:       6685 :     if (nHeight >= consensusParams.SegwitHeight) {
    3583                 :       6558 :         int commitpos = GetWitnessCommitmentIndex(block);
    3584         [ +  - ]:       6558 :         if (commitpos != NO_WITNESS_COMMITMENT) {
    3585                 :       6558 :             bool malleated = false;
    3586                 :       6558 :             uint256 hashWitness = BlockWitnessMerkleRoot(block, &malleated);
    3587                 :            :             // The malleation check is ignored; as the transaction tree itself
    3588                 :            :             // already does not permit it, it is impossible to trigger in the
    3589                 :            :             // witness tree.
    3590   [ +  -  +  - ]:       6558 :             if (block.vtx[0]->vin[0].scriptWitness.stack.size() != 1 || block.vtx[0]->vin[0].scriptWitness.stack[0].size() != 32) {
    3591   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                 return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_MUTATED, "bad-witness-nonce-size", strprintf("%s : invalid witness reserved value size", __func__));
             #  #  #  # ]
    3592                 :            :             }
    3593                 :       6558 :             CHash256().Write(hashWitness).Write(block.vtx[0]->vin[0].scriptWitness.stack[0]).Finalize(hashWitness);
    3594   [ -  +  -  + ]:      13116 :             if (memcmp(hashWitness.begin(), &block.vtx[0]->vout[commitpos].scriptPubKey[6], 32)) {
    3595   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                 return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_MUTATED, "bad-witness-merkle-match", strprintf("%s : witness merkle commitment mismatch", __func__));
             #  #  #  # ]
    3596                 :            :             }
    3597                 :            :             fHaveWitness = true;
    3598                 :            :         }
    3599                 :            :     }
    3600                 :            : 
    3601                 :            :     // No witness data is allowed in blocks that don't commit to witness data, as this would otherwise leave room for spam
    3602                 :            :     if (!fHaveWitness) {
    3603         [ +  + ]:       1390 :       for (const auto& tx : block.vtx) {
    3604         [ -  + ]:       1263 :             if (tx->HasWitness()) {
    3605   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                 return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_MUTATED, "unexpected-witness", strprintf("%s : unexpected witness data found", __func__));
             #  #  #  # ]

    3607                 :            :         }
    3608                 :            :     }
    3609                 :            : 
    3610                 :            :     // After the coinbase witness reserved value and commitment are verified,
    3611                 :            :     // we can check if the block weight passes (before we've checked the
    3612                 :            :     // coinbase witness, it would be possible for the weight to be too
    3613                 :            :     // large by filling up the coinbase witness, which doesn't change
    3614                 :            :     // the block hash, so we couldn't mark the block as permanently

    3662                 :            : 
    3663                 :            :         /* Determine if this block descends from any block which has been found
    3664                 :            :          * invalid (m_failed_blocks), then mark pindexPrev and any blocks between
    3665                 :            :          * them as failed. For example:
    3666                 :            :          *
    3667                 :            :          *                D3
    3668                 :            :          *              /
    3669                 :            :          *      B2 - C2
    3670                 :            :          *    /         \
    3671                 :            :          *  A             D2 - E2 - F2
    3672                 :            :          *    \
    3673                 :            :          *      B1 - C1 - D1 - E1
    3674                 :            :          *
    3675                 :            :          * In the case that we attempted to reorg from E1 to F2, only to find
    3676                 :            :          * C2 to be invalid, we would mark D2, E2, and F2 as BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD
    3677                 :            :          * but NOT D3 (it was not in any of our candidate sets at the time).
    3678                 :            :          *
    3679                 :            :          * In any case D3 will also be marked as BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD at restart
    3680                 :            :          * in LoadBlockIndex.
    3681                 :            :          */
    3682   [ +  -  +  + ]:       3350 :         if (!pindexPrev->IsValid(BLOCK_VALID_SCRIPTS)) {

    3684                 :            :             // hasn't been validated up to BLOCK_VALID_SCRIPTS. This is a performance

    4384                 :            : 
    4385                 :          0 : bool CChainState::ReplayBlocks(const CChainParams& params)
    4386                 :            : {
    4387                 :          0 :     LOCK(cs_main);
    4388                 :            : 
    4389         [ #  # ]:          0 :     CCoinsView& db = this->CoinsDB();
    4390   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     CCoinsViewCache cache(&db);
    4391                 :            : 
    4392         [ #  # ]:          0 :     std::vector<uint256> hashHeads = db.GetHeadBlocks();
    4393         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (hashHeads.empty()) return true; // We're already in a consistent state.
    4394   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     if (hashHeads.size() != 2) return error("ReplayBlocks(): unknown inconsistent state");
    4395                 :            : 
    4396   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     uiInterface.ShowProgress(_("Replaying blocks...").translated, 0, false);
    4397         [ #  # ]:          0 :     LogPrintf("Replaying blocks\n");
    4398                 :            : 
    4399                 :          0 :     const CBlockIndex* pindexOld = nullptr;  // Old tip during the interrupted flush.
    4400                 :          0 :     const CBlockIndex* pindexNew;            // New tip during the interrupted flush.
    4401                 :          0 :     const CBlockIndex* pindexFork = nullptr; // Latest block common to both the old and the new tip.
    4402                 :            : 
    4403         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (m_blockman.m_block_index.count(hashHeads[0]) == 0) {
    4404         [ #  # ]:          0 :         return error("ReplayBlocks(): reorganization to unknown block requested");
    4405                 :            :     }
    4406         [ #  # ]:          0 :     pindexNew = m_blockman.m_block_index[hashHeads[0]];
    4407                 :            : 
    4408         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (!hashHeads[1].IsNull()) { // The old tip is allowed to be 0, indicating it's the first flush.
    4409         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (m_blockman.m_block_index.count(hashHeads[1]) == 0) {
    4410         [ #  # ]:          0 :             return error("ReplayBlocks(): reorganization from unknown block requested");
    4411                 :            :         }
    4412         [ #  # ]:          0 :         pindexOld = m_blockman.m_block_index[hashHeads[1]];
    4413         [ #  # ]:          0 :         pindexFork = LastCommonAncestor(pindexOld, pindexNew);
    4414         [ #  # ]:          0 :         assert(pindexFork != nullptr);
    4415                 :            :     }
    4416                 :            : 
    4417                 :            :     // Rollback along the old branch.
    4418         [ #  # ]:          0 :     while (pindexOld != pindexFork) {
    4419         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (pindexOld->nHeight > 0) { // Never disconnect the genesis block.
    4420                 :          0 :             CBlock block;
    4421   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             if (!ReadBlockFromDisk(block, pindexOld, params.GetConsensus())) {
    4422   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                 return error("RollbackBlock(): ReadBlockFromDisk() failed at %d, hash=%s", pindexOld->nHeight, pindexOld->GetBlockHash().ToString());
                   #  # ]
    4423                 :            :             }
    4424   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             LogPrintf("Rolling back %s (%i)\n", pindexOld->GetBlockHash().ToString(), pindexOld->nHeight);
    4425         [ #  # ]:          0 :             DisconnectResult res = DisconnectBlock(block, pindexOld, cache);
    4426         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (res == DISCONNECT_FAILED) {
    4427   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                 return error("RollbackBlock(): DisconnectBlock failed at %d, hash=%s", pindexOld->nHeight, pindexOld->GetBlockHash().ToString());
                   #  # ]
    4428                 :            :             }
    4429                 :            :             // If DISCONNECT_UNCLEAN is returned, it means a non-existing UTXO was deleted, or an existing UTXO was
    4430                 :            :             // overwritten. It corresponds to cases where the block-to-be-disconnect never had all its operations
    4431                 :            :             // applied to the UTXO set. However, as both writing a UTXO and deleting a UTXO are idempotent operations,
    4432                 :            :             // the result is still a version of the UTXO set with the effects of that block undone.
    4433                 :            :         }
    4434                 :          0 :         pindexOld = pindexOld->pprev;
    4435                 :            :     }
    4436                 :            : 
    4437                 :            :     // Roll forward from the forking point to the new tip.

    4488                 :          0 : bool CChainState::RewindBlockIndex(const CChainParams& params)
    4489                 :            : {
    4490                 :            :     // Note that during -reindex-chainstate we are called with an empty m_chain!
    4491                 :            : 
    4492                 :            :     // First erase all post-segwit blocks without witness not in the main chain,
    4493                 :            :     // as this can we done without costly DisconnectTip calls. Active
    4494                 :            :     // blocks will be dealt with below (releasing cs_main in between).

    4500                 :            :             }
    4501                 :            :         }

    4525   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     while (!ShutdownRequested()) {
    4526                 :          0 :         {
    4527         [ #  # ]:          0 :             LOCK(cs_main);
    4528   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             LOCK(m_mempool.cs);
    4529                 :            :             // Make sure nothing changed from under us (this won't happen because RewindBlockIndex runs before importing/network are active)
    4530   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             assert(tip == m_chain.Tip());
    4531   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             if (tip == nullptr || tip->nHeight < nHeight) break;
    4532   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             if (fPruneMode && !(tip->nStatus & BLOCK_HAVE_DATA)) {
    4533                 :            :                 // If pruning, don't try rewinding past the HAVE_DATA point;
    4534                 :            :                 // since older blocks can't be served anyway, there's
    4535                 :            :                 // no need to walk further, and trying to DisconnectTip()
    4536                 :            :                 // will fail (and require a needless reindex/redownload
    4537                 :            :                 // of the blockchain).
    4538                 :            :                 break;
    4539                 :            :             }
    4540                 :            : 
    4541                 :            :             // Disconnect block

             #  #  #  # ]
    4544                 :            :             }
    4545                 :            : 
    4546                 :            :             // Reduce validity flag and have-data flags.
    4547                 :            :             // We do this after actual disconnecting, otherwise we'll end up writing the lack of data
    4548                 :            :             // to disk before writing the chainstate, resulting in a failure to continue if interrupted.
    4549                 :            :             // Note: If we encounter an insufficiently validated block that
    4550                 :            :             // is on m_chain, it must be because we are a pruning node, and
    4551                 :            :             // this block or some successor doesn't HAVE_DATA, so we were unable to

    4789                 :      20861 : void CChainState::CheckBlockIndex(const Consensus::Params& consensusParams)
    4790                 :            : {
    4791         [ +  - ]:      20861 :     if (!fCheckBlockIndex) {
    4792                 :            :         return;
    4793                 :            :     }
    4794                 :            : 
    4795                 :      20861 :     LOCK(cs_main);
    4796                 :            : 
    4797                 :            :     // During a reindex, we read the genesis block and call CheckBlockIndex before ActivateBestChain,
    4798                 :            :     // so we have the genesis block in m_blockman.m_block_index but no active chain. (A few of the
